title: What Is an Ectopic Beat?
author: Markham Heid

content: "Ectopic" means something that is in an odd place or position. In the case of an ectopic beat, that oddly placed something is your heartbeat.
You may hear people call this condition an early, missed, or extra heartbeat. It happens because something goes wrong with your heart's electrical system.
The idea of your heartbeat going rogue may sound alarming. But in most cases, an ectopic beat is a harmless condition. It's also a common one. It's more common in older people.

content_blocks.text: "Ectopic" means something that is in an odd place or position. In the case of an ectopic beat, that oddly placed something is your heartbeat.
You may hear people call this condition an early, missed, or extra heartbeat. It happens because something goes wrong with your heart's electrical system.
The idea of your heartbeat going rogue may sound alarming. But in most cases, an ectopic beat is a harmless condition. It's also a common one. It's more common in older people.

sections.heading: How It Happens
content: Your heart contains four main sections, called chambers. The upper two are the atria, and the lower two are the ventricles.
Electrical signals control your heartbeat. These signals normally come from an area of cells known as the sinus node, which is in the upper right atrium.
During a typical heartbeat, these electrical signals cause the two atria to squeeze or "contract." Afterward, the two ventricles do likewise.
In some cases, electrical signals can also come from outside of the sinus node. These can cause either the atria or the ventricles to squeeze a little too soon. The result: an ectopic beat.

content_blocks.text: Your heart contains four main sections, called chambers. The upper two are the atria, and the lower two are the ventricles.
Electrical signals control your heartbeat. These signals normally come from an area of cells known as the sinus node, which is in the upper right atrium.
During a typical heartbeat, these electrical signals cause the two atria to squeeze or "contract." Afterward, the two ventricles do likewise.
In some cases, electrical signals can also come from outside of the sinus node. These can cause either the atria or the ventricles to squeeze a little too soon. The result: an ectopic beat.

sections.heading: Types of Ectopic Beats
content: Not all ectopic beats are the same. There are two main types:
Premature atrial contractions (PACs). These are ectopic beats that happen in the upper chambers of the heart.
Premature ventricular contractions (PVCs). These ectopic beats take place in the lower chambers of the heart.
Ectopic beats happen more commonly in the atria than in the ventricles.

Ectopic beats happen more commonly in the atria than in the ventricles.

sections.heading: Symptoms
content: If you have ectopic beats, you may not notice any symptoms. If you do have symptoms, the most common are sensations in your chest such as:
bullets: Become more aware that your heart is beating

associated_bullets: Become more aware that your heart is beating

sections.heading: Causes of Ectopic Beats
content: Doctors aren't always sure what causes an ectopic beat, but some things can trigger it, such as:
bullets: Some medications , including decongestants and antihistamines
Anything that causes the heart to race, such as alcohol, caffeine , and anxiety

Anything that causes the heart to race, such as alcohol, caffeine , and anxiety

sections.heading: Diagnosis
content: If you feel your heart flutter or miss a beat now and then, that's normal. It's usually nothing to worry about.

content_blocks.text: If you feel your heart flutter or miss a beat now and then, that's normal. It's usually nothing to worry about.

content: But if your heart seems to miss or skip a beat regularly, or more than it used to, tell your doctor. They may be able to diagnose an ectopic beat by listening to your heart.
Your doctor may also need to give you heart tests , such as an electrocardiogram ( EKG ), to figure out if an ectopic beat is causing your symptoms.

The doctor may also ask you to wear a Holter monitor, a device that keeps tabs on your heart rhythm. It will help evaluate the beats, check how often they're happening, and make sure there are no other problems besides the ectopic beats.
Even if you don't have any symptoms, one of these tests may reveal that you have an ectopic beat.

content_blocks.text: But if your heart seems to miss or skip a beat regularly, or more than it used to, tell your doctor. They may be able to diagnose an ectopic beat by listening to your heart.
Your doctor may also need to give you heart tests , such as an electrocardiogram ( EKG ), to figure out if an ectopic beat is causing your symptoms.

The doctor may also ask you to wear a Holter monitor, a device that keeps tabs on your heart rhythm. It will help evaluate the beats, check how often they're happening, and make sure there are no other problems besides the ectopic beats.
Even if you don't have any symptoms, one of these tests may reveal that you have an ectopic beat.

sections.heading: Treatment
content: Your doctor may suggest that you avoid the things that trigger your ectopic beat. For example, if anxiety is a trigger for you, you might benefit from stress -lowering techniques like meditation .
In some cases, medication may be a solution. These include beta-blockers and other drugs that change the way the heart responds to hormones or electrical signals.
A procedure called radiofrequency catheter ablation may help. Your doctor silences a portion of the heart's electrical signaling with "radiofrequency energy," which is a bit like microwave heat.

content_blocks.text: Your doctor may suggest that you avoid the things that trigger your ectopic beat. For example, if anxiety is a trigger for you, you might benefit from stress -lowering techniques like meditation .
In some cases, medication may be a solution. These include beta-blockers and other drugs that change the way the heart responds to hormones or electrical signals.
A procedure called radiofrequency catheter ablation may help. Your doctor silences a portion of the heart's electrical signaling with "radiofrequency energy," which is a bit like microwave heat.

sections.heading: Complications
content: There's some evidence that an ectopic beat can raise your chances of getting heart trouble or lung disease. That's another good reason to talk to your doctor about anything about your heart that doesn't seem normal.

sources: European Medical Journal: "Ectopic Beats: How Many Count?"
Mayo Clinic: "Premature Ventricular Contractions (PVCs): Symptoms & causes," "Premature Ventricular Contractions (PVCs): Diagnosis & treatment," "Holter monitor."
BMJ Heart: "Ectopic Beats – Frequent, Troublesome and not to be Dismissed."
meta_description: Find out what might trigger an ectopic beat -- also called an early, missed, or extra heartbeat -- and how you can treat it.
